title: 111_hr5779
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act". The table of contents of this Act is as follows: The "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act" includes provisions such as termination of Federal commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers, termination of the Forest Service Economic Action Program, termination of grants to manufacturers of worsted wool fabrics, termination of a health care services program for the Delta region, termination of energy efficiency grants in rural communities, revised income limitations for agricultural payments, and new limits on payments to producers of certain commodities. The "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act" includes provisions such as new limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities, reduction in payment acres for commodity programs, reduction in funding for market access program, reduction in reimbursement rate for private insurance companies under crop insurance program, and prohibition on timber sales in specific regions of the National Forest System. The bill includes termination of federal commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers, termination of Forest Service Economic Action Program, termination of grants to manufacturers of worsted wool fabrics, and termination of Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region. Section 379G of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act and Section 19 of the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 are repealed. Revised adjusted gross income limitations are implemented for various agricultural payments and benefits. The revised income limitations for commodity programs and direct payments under the Food Security Act of 1985 are as follows: $500,000 for 2009-2010, $420,000 for 2011, $340,000 for 2012, and $250,000 for 2013 onwards for non-farm income. For farm income, the limits are $750,000 for 2009-2010 and $670,000 for 2011. The non-farm income limitations for conservation programs under the Food Security Act of 1985 have been revised as follows: $1,000,000 for 2009-2010, $670,000 for 2011, $590,000 for 2012, and $500,000 for 2013 onwards. The non-farm income limitations for conservation programs under the Food Security Act of 1985 have been revised to $1,000,000 for 2009-2010, $920,000 for 2011, $840,000 for 2012, and $750,000 for 2013 onwards. SEC. 8. NEW LIMITS ON PAYMENTS TO PRODUCERS OF AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES. New limits on payments to producers of agricultural commodities are being implemented. Direct payments for covered commodities are reduced from $40,000 to $20,000, while counter-cyclical payments are reduced from $65,000 to $32,500. Similar reductions apply to ACRE and counter-cyclical payments for peanuts as well. New limits on payments to producers of agricultural commodities are being implemented, with direct payments reduced from $40,000 to $20,000 and counter-cyclical payments reduced from $65,000 to $32,500. This also applies to ACRE and counter-cyclical payments for peanuts. SEC. 9. ONE PERCENT REDUCTION IN PAYMENT ACRES FOR COMMODITY PROGRAMS. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 is amended to define 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments based on crop years. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 is amended to define 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments for covered commodities and peanuts based on specific percentages of base acres for different crop years. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 amended the definition of 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments for covered commodities and peanuts based on specific percentages of base acres for different crop years. SEC. 10 amends the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to reduce funding for the Market Access Program. SEC. 11 reduces the reimbursement rate paid to private insurance companies under the Crop Insurance Program. SEC. 11 amends the Federal Crop Insurance Act to reduce the reimbursement rate paid to private insurance companies. The amendment specifies decreasing percentages for different reinsurance years, starting from 27% for 1998 and ending at 20.9% for 2011 and subsequent years. SEC. 12 prohibits timber sales in certain regions of the National Forest System where Federal expenditures exceed offsetting receipts until timber sales can generate enough receipts to cover the costs.
